Award.AwardTitle: A Proposal to Support Undergraduate Research and Communitiy Training in Applications of LTER and NEON Data at Southwest Indian Polytechnic Institute
Award.AbstractNarration: This award will expand the capacity of Southwest Indian Polytechnic Institute (SIPI) to 1) provide comprehensive geospatial training to tribal students and tribal members across the region and the country by supporting summer training of Tribal College and University students for careers in sciences with a foundation in geospatial information technology, 2) provide geospatial technology professional development for tribal natural resource professionals, and 3) engage tribal college and tribal professionals in national research and technology efforts such as the NSF Long Term Ecological Research (LTER) Program and the National Ecological Observation Network (NEON). Founded in 1971, and acquiring Land Grant status in 1994, SIPI provides higher education opportunities for indigenous people from over 100 different tribes across the United States. The overall objectives of the workshops are to expand SIPI's capacity to provide geospatial training, to expand opportunities for Tribal College and University undergraduate students to engage in scientific research, and to develop an understanding of long-term and large scale ecological research provided by LTER and NEON. The workshops will bring in guest speakers from NEON, and provide training from LTER scientists. Other activities include a visit to NEON HQ and using NEON data in summer courses at SIPI. The summer courses will serve an estimated 80 students from American Indian and Alaska Native tribes. The effort will occur as part of the SIPI Geospatial Information Technology Summer Institute, which has been held since 2000, and was institutionalized in 2004. This summer program will expand science education through this minority serving institution with cutting edge ecological research. Courses held this summer are estimated to serve eighty students from American Indian and Alaska Native tribes with potential for more enrollments in several classes. This effort will expand the number of underrepresented groups engaged in science and technology education and research.

Project Outcomes Report:

A PROPOSAL TO SUPPORT UNDERGRADUATE RESEARCH AND COMMUNITY TRAINING IN APPLICATIONS OF LTER AND NEON DATA AT SOUTHWESTERN INDIAN POLYTECHNIC INSTITUTE

 

Objectives: Founded in 1971, and acquiring Land Grant status in 1994, Southwestern Indian Polytechnic Institute (SIPI) provides higher education opportunities for indigenous people from over 100 different tribes across the United States. The NSF proposal was developed with three main objectives. Those objectives are to 1) prepare students for careers in sciences with a foundation in geospatial information technology, 2) provide geospatial technology professional development for tribal natural resource professionals; and 3) provide access for tribal college and tribal professional participation in the growing National Ecological Observation Network. The three objectives were met with successful summer short course programs, during which SIPI hosted 65 students and 90 Native American professionals in 14 classes over the past two years as well as through eleven internships, seven of them paid internships through this grant. The internship students benefitted from the expert mentoring funded by this grant and presented their work at national conferences.

 

Intellectual Merit: The 2012 and 2013 summer programs expanded science education through this minority serving institution by providing students exposure to research methodology and training using the GIS lab, providing expert mentoring in research techniques, and providing students with a platform to speak about and demonstrate the methods they learned while working on their chosen projects. This was accomplished by inviting guest speakers from Jornada and Sevilleta research stations, providing training on how to utilize LTER data, visiting NEON headquarters with the project PI and undergraduate research students, and by integrating LTER and NEON-like data into the summer course curriculum.

 

Broad Impact Statement: Providing training in geospatial technology to tribal professionals from all over the United States is building tribal capacity to use NEON data when it comes online. In continuation of this effort, courses held this during the summer of 2014 are estimated to serve 75 students from American Indian and Alaska Native tribes with potential for more enrollment in several classes. This effort has expanded the number of underrepresented groups engaged in science and technology education and research.

 

Participants in 2012 and 2013 have gained valuable geospatial and technical skills, and gained access to the NEON and LTER network of scientists and engineers that will be the cornerstone for new relationships and projects to come. Participants have also been successful in presenting NEON internship projects during national conferences. One student and the geospatial lab technician attended the ESRI Users Conference in 2012. In 2014, a NEON internship student applied to and was accepted for internships at NASA and Sevilleta LTER expanding her research skills, and she will be presenting her NEON project in August at the Ecological Society of America Conference. Finally, two more students will present their projects during the tribal track at the ESRI User’s Conference, July 2014. 

 

Work done accomplishing the objectives of the project solidified SIPI’s relationship with both NEON and the LTER’s.
